data.name: PID Controller
data.description:
A PID controller (proportional-integral-derivative controller) is a feedback mechanism commonly used for engineering purposes. A PID controller continuously measures the error (Set Point - Current Point) and passes it through each of the three terms to yield and output. To make a PID controller accurate for a given purpose, it is tuned using three constants: K<sub>p</sub>, K<sub>i</sub>, and K<sub>d</sub>. The equation of a PID controller looks something like this:

![pid equation](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1bcb82541c2fd40dd893d3893e04b4d6b1f02330)

In this Kata, your task will be to write three methods: `calculateP` (or `calculate_p`), `calculateI` (or `calculate_i`), and `calculateD` (or `calculate_d`). In each method, you'll be given parameters of `setPoint`, `measuredValue`, and `K`<sub>x</sub> where x is the appropriate term. In the case of `calculateI`, you will also be passed a parameter `integral` since discrete time implementations often rely on summation to work. `integral` will be the summated previous error values. For `calculateD`, you will also receive a parameter `timeElapsed` which contains time elapsed since last call and `prevError` which contains the previous iterations error, since discrete time implementations of a PID controller often take the average rate of change since last call.

To recap, this is what your class methods should look like:
```java
calculateP(double setPoint, double measuredValue, double Kp);
calculateI(double setPoint, double measuredValue, double Ki, double integral);
calculateD(double setPoint, double measuredValue, double Kd, double timeElapsed, double prevError);
```
```python
calculate_p(set_point, measured_value, Kp)
calculate_i(set_point, measured_value, Ki, integral)
calculate_d(set_point, measured_value, Kd, time_elapsed, prev_error)
```
In Python, results should be rounded off to 4 decimal places. In Java, a tolerance of 1E-5 will be given and results should not be rounded. This is because the Java test API supports a delta while the Python one does not.

##Further Reading
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PID_controller

##Notes
Remember that `integral` is already adjusted for the constant value of K<sub>i</sub> since it resulted from a previous iteration of our algorithm.
